Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Uprisings and Political Outcomes in the MENA Region

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Uprisings and Political Outcomes in the MENA Region



This project seeks to explain the emergence and outcomes of contemporary regional revolutionary waves. Recent Middle East-North African history provides exceptional cases to test and enrich related theories. Beginning late 2010, the Arab Spring concatenation of mass movements challenged regimes? right to rule, police states, and economic-development orientations. By early 2011, many saw these uprisings as initiating democracy and social justice across MENA. Yet, uprisings emerged in only six MENA countries; others had reformist or few protests; and later outcomes contradicted demands. Consider the political despair, the imprisoned or dead, the masses made refugees, compared to popular calls for socioeconomic wellbeing or democratic empowerment. Of the six uprisings, four ousted long-standing rulers (Tunisia, Egypt, Yemen, Libya) and two were deflected (Bahrain, Syria). Tunisia alone would then transition to political democracy; Egypt's military and Bahrain's monarchy institutionalized autocratic counterrevolutions; and Yemen, Libya, and Syria descended into internationalized civil wars. This project seeks to explain these three interrelated outcomes: namely, why uprisings emerged in some regional countries and not others (revolution emergence); why some uprisings ousted rulers and others did not (initial political outcomes); and lastly, why cases produced political democracy, counterrevolution, or civil war (major political outcomes). This project addresses theoretical debates on the oppositional movements, political and economic regimes, and global relations impacting revolutions. The project analyzes the contingent dynamics of social, state, and global actors contending to transform or retain autocracy and neoliberalism, and the institutional-structural terrains conditioning these struggles and outcomes. By splitting cases into multiple episodes and outcomes, not single isolated-linear processes, this project enhances knowledge of successful/positive, failed/negative, and reversed cases amid revolutionary waves.

This project uses comparative historical-sociological methods for in-depth case studies and comparisons, and multi-level, combinatorial, and interactive causal analysis. First, the project uses fuzzy-set/Qualitative Comparative Analysis of 21 MENA countries to locate causal combinations for revolution emergence, no emergence, and reformist protest. Fuzzy sets allow fine gradations in degrees of set membership in potential causal factors, rather than neatly-defined fixed sets, which enables evaluating complex causation. This project creates composite indexes to determine countries' set membership scores in oppositional mobilizing structures, sultanistic-autocratic regimes, rentier states, uneven development, and neoliberal globalization, with fs/QCA locating necessary and/or sufficient combinations of these factors for the specified outcomes. These combinations are analyzed vis-Ã -vis case interaction/revolutionary diffusion. Second, this project uses within- and cross-case analysis for three full and three mini case studies. Case analysis prioritizes the impact of movement composition and action-forms, state-military structures, and global relations on the initial and major political outcomes. Dense event timelines are created using event-level data from organizational reports and systematically-gathered newspaper data, generating analytical sketches of actors' activities and interests, protest events and cycles, and institutional changes. Semi-structured in-depth interviews of movement organizers further ground this project. By processually studying positive, negative, and reversed cases, this project will explain why many Arab Spring cases defy existing revolution theories and inform movement activists and political leaders on the nature, durability, and change of autocratic regimes and exploitative economic systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project follows an enduring and consequential phenomenon: revolutionary social movements and their political outcomes. This concern is deep-rooted, but also timely, setting out from 2011, which is seen as a year of global uprisings. Links on the Chain: Popular Uprisings and Political Re-constitutions in the Global Middle East and North Africa investigates the regional epicenter of that global diffusion of protests, covering classic questions in political sociology on how social structures and human actions interact in revolutions.

 

I study revolutionary struggles erupting in sequence across a world region to explain some of their successes, failures, and reversals. To do so, I “disaggregate” revolutions into a series of episodes: 1) emergence; 2) mass attack on the ruling regime; and 3) transitional struggle over the revolution’s institutional content and resulting power configuration. I ask: why do masses of people collectively act to fundamentally change their societies? Why do some revolution attempts topple entrenched rulers, others do so only with external help, and still others fail? Lastly, why do initially successful cases transition into either democratized rule or restored autocracy? To address these puzzles, I use multiple analytic methods and first zoom out to consider all regional countries, then take on the smaller number of cases, and finally hone in on two “core” cases in the revolutionary wave.

 

First, I argue that revolution’s emergence is inter-societal, and the 2011 Arab revolutionary wave, the initial and the later uprisings had different causes, while several conditions stopped revolution from spreading elsewhere. The initial cases have an ‘ideal-typic’ causal configuration, as multiple factors co-occurred to entrench social worlds of wrenching tensions, sparking a revolutionary wave where a smaller number of expected causes drove the first set of downstream cases and still an even smaller number drove the second set. Prior research notes this general diffusion dynamic, but not the actual causal combinations spread across the unfolding of cases. This chapter unravels this diffusion and demonstrates when certain conditions, like movements or global ties, are important, and when they are not. I contend that later cases are linked to specific causal configurations and forms of strategic thinking, not just external ‘contagion-like’ effects.

 

Second, ousting an entrenched ruler here occurs when broad revolutionary movements 1) include working-class mobilization and 2) confront bureaucratic militaries. Collective labor actions help create the power to drive relatively autonomous, coherent national militaries to divorce political regimes. The absence of this combination sees mass attacks on regimes followed by military repression or war, and regime persistence if there is no 3) direct foreign intervention to change the regime. Prior research has already enshrined the two major causal factors, multiclass coalitions and “sultanistic” regimes, but is less specific on what actually empowers movements and the role of key state institutions, namely the military. My findings suggest the importance of combining movements, namely how social composition and form of action links to structural and associational power, with prioritizing political-military institutions.

 

Third, I examine organized labor and workers movements in longer-term outcomes in Tunisia and Egypt, namely vis-à-vis constitution-making. In both, labor led remarkable constitutional draft campaigns to breach formal constitution-making processes, but only Tunisia’s UGTT succeeded and helped democratize rule while Egyptian labor saw autocracy restored. I argue that key to these divergent outcomes is the organized disruptive capacity of nonelite/nonstate actors – those who can sustain multi-tactic campaigns overtime; deploy protest mobilization strategically, link collective actions to high-capacity economic sectors, and decisively negotiate and make decisions. This concept ties together recent insights on structural power and protests, with insights on labor organization and leadership, which enriches scholarly and popular images of the Arab uprisings as spontaneous or networked protests. My contributions are four-fold. First, I clarify the concept of organized disruptive capacity by bringing democratic transitions and social/labor movement research into the study of revolutions. Second, I offer an addendum to dominant theories on militaries and Islamist-secular divides in these cases. Third, I contribute to research on constitutions by showing constitution-making processes and contents impacting outcomes. Lastly, I introduce original data from organizational archival materials and key participant interviews.

 

This final segment is most focused on what people can do to bring major structural change, so it has the clearest implications for social movements. I build on those who are skeptical of the power of mass mobilizational bursts to bring desired change. I show what happens to a movement when it lacks the organizational cohesion and multi-level leadership to strategically deploy protests and class power in order to negotiate the fate of change, and through comparative analysis of two movements seeking to shape constitutions, the study clarifies the high-bar for popular movements to steer transitional outcomes amid fierce adversities. The chapter also blurs the boundary between “political” and “social” revolutions, and discusses challenges and opportunities for movements that create political but not socioeconomic change.

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2019
Modified by: Tyson Patros
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project follows an enduring and consequential phenomenon: revolutionary social movements and their political outcomes. This concern is deep-rooted, but also timely, setting out from 2011, which is seen as a year of global uprisings. Links on the Chain: Popular Uprisings and Political Re-constitutions in the Global Middle East and North Africa investigates the regional epicenter of that global diffusion of protests, covering classic questions in political sociology on how social structures and human actions interact in revolutions. I study revolutionary struggles erupting in sequence across a world region to explain some of their successes, failures, and reversals. To do so, I "disaggregate" revolutions into a series of episodes: 1) emergence; 2) mass attack on the ruling regime; and 3) transitional struggle over the revolution?s institutional content and resulting power configuration. I ask: why do masses of people collectively act to fundamentally change their societies? Why do some revolution attempts topple entrenched rulers, others do so only with external help, and still others fail? Lastly, why do initially successful cases transition into either democratized rule or restored autocracy? To address these puzzles, I use multiple analytic methods and first zoom out to consider all regional countries, then take on the smaller number of cases, and finally hone in on two "core" cases in the revolutionary wave. First, I argue that revolution?s emergence is inter-societal, and the 2011 Arab revolutionary wave, the initial and the later uprisings had different causes, while several conditions stopped revolution from spreading elsewhere. The initial cases have an ?ideal-typic? causal configuration, as multiple factors co-occurred to entrench social worlds of wrenching tensions, sparking a revolutionary wave where a smaller number of expected causes drove the first set of downstream cases and still an even smaller number drove the second set. Prior research notes this general diffusion dynamic, but not the actual causal combinations spread across the unfolding of cases. Third, I examine organized labor and workers movements in longer-term outcomes in Tunisia and Egypt, namely vis-à-vis constitution-making. This concept ties together recent insights on structural power and protests, with insights on labor organization and leadership, which enriches scholarly and popular images of the Arab uprisings as spontaneous or networked protests. My contributions are four-fold. First, I clarify the concept of organized disruptive capacity by bringing democratic transitions and social/labor movement research into the study of revolutions. Second, I offer an addendum to dominant theories on militaries and Islamist-secular divides in these cases. Third, I contribute to research on constitutions by showing constitution-making processes and contents impacting outcomes. This final segment is most focused on what people can do to bring major structural change, so it has the clearest implications for social movements. I build on those who are skeptical of the power of mass mobilizational bursts to bring desired change. I show what happens to a movement when it lacks the organizational cohesion and multi-level leadership to strategically deploy protests and class power in order to negotiate the fate of change, and through comparative analysis of two movements seeking to shape constitutions, the study clarifies the high-bar for popular movements to steer transitional outcomes amid fierce adversities. The chapter also blurs the boundary between "political" and "social" revolutions, and discusses challenges and opportunities for movements that create political but not socioeconomic change.
